questionList.questionText: A 25-year-old woman comes to the office due to weight gain.  The patient has gained 4.5 kg (10 lb) since breaking up with her boyfriend and starting a stressful job 4 months ago.  She says, "I hate the way I look.  I try to limit my portions, but several times a week I end up eating a whole bag of cookies or a quart of ice cream in one sitting, even if I'm not hungry.  My stomach is so bloated that I can't fit into my clothes.  It is so depressing."  The patient has had abdominal discomfort but no nausea or vomiting.  Her weight is always fluctuating although she has tried numerous diets over the years.  She also does 45 minutes of aerobic exercise 3 times a week.  The patient prefers to eat alone because she feels embarrassed and "out of control."  She feels guilty about her behavior, and her self-esteem is low.  The patient is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb).  BMI is 23.4 kg/m2.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Eating disorders

Diagnosis

Clinical features

Treatment

Anorexia nervosa

  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views of body weight & shape
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to first-line treatments

Bulimia nervosa

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Inappropriate compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain
  • Excessive worrying about body shape & weight
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • SSRI (fluoxetine), often in combination with first-line treatments

Binge eating disorder

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • No inappropriate compensatory behaviors
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Behavioral weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisdexamfetamine, topiramate

SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's recurrent episodes of binge eating and the absence of recurrent unhealthy compensatory behaviors seen in bulimia nervosa (eg, self-induced vomiting, fasting, laxative abuse, excessive exercise) are consistent with binge eating disorder (BED).  Diagnosis requires ≥1 episode per week of binge eating (ie, consuming an excessively large amount of food in a discrete period of time) over 3 months.

Other characteristic features of BED include a sense of loss of control, eating rapidly until uncomfortably full, eating when not hungry, eating alone due to embarrassment, and distress, depression, disgust, or guilt after overeating.  BED is the most common eating disorder.  Although many patients with BED are overweight, it also occurs in patients with normal weight, as in this case.

The treatment of choice for BED is psychotherapy, with the best evidence for cognitive-behavioral therapy.  Additional treatment options for patients with BED who are overweight or obese include behavioral weight loss therapy and pharmacotherapy with the stimulant lisdexamfetamine.

(Choice A)  This patient describes years of weight fluctuations, suggesting that her abnormal eating behavior predated her recent stressors.  Stress often exacerbates underlying disorders.

(Choice C)  Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by obsessive preoccupation with nonexistent or slight defects in physical appearance.  It is not diagnosed in patients who are mainly concerned about weight and who also meet criteria for an eating disorder.

(Choice D)  This patient does not engage in the recurrent and excessive compensatory behaviors required to diagnose bulimia nervosa.  Her attempts to diet over the years are characteristic of patients with BED, and her 3-times/week exercise regimen is within healthy guidelines.  In contrast, patients with bulimia nervosa engage in periods of excessive fasting and/or extreme exercise undertaken specifically to compensate for their binge episodes.

(Choice E)  Irritable bowel syndrome is characterized by chronic abdominal pain and irregular bowel movements (diarrhea and/or constipation), which this patient does not describe.

Educational objective:
Binge eating disorder is characterized by episodes of binge eating associated with distress and a sense of loss of control.  It is differentiated from bulimia nervosa by the absence of recurrent, unhealthy compensatory behaviors (eg, self-induced vomiting, fasting, excessive exercise).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Binge eating disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A primer on binge eating disorder diagnosis and management.
Binge eating disorder.
Overview of the treatment of binge eating disorder.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening generalized weakness.  The patient has also had occasional palpitations, muscle cramps, abdominal bloating, and constipation.  She reports no chronic medical conditions, but 6 months ago she was hospitalized due to bloody emesis and was found to have a Mallory-Weiss tear.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 10/min.  BMI is 24.6 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows anicteric sclera, dry oral mucosa, dental caries, and bilateral swollen cheeks.  The lungs are clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender with no organomegaly.  There is mild lower extremity edema.  Skin is dry without any rashes.  Muscle strength is mildly decreased throughout.  Which of the following sets of findings are most likely to be present in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
The physical examination findings of dry skin, dental caries, bilateral swollen cheeks (parotid gland enlargement), and history of a Mallory-Weiss tear are consistent with surreptitious, self-induced vomiting, suggesting a diagnosis of bulimia nervosa (BN).  Because patients with eating disorders often attempt to hide their condition, physical examination and laboratory assessment are often key to making the diagnosis.

Excessive vomiting, which is commonly seen in BN, causes multiple metabolic derangements.  Loss of hydrochloric acid and potassium in the vomit results in a hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis (ie, elevated pH, low chloride).  Dehydration and volume contraction result in activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which causes secondary hyperaldosteronism and further worsens these abnormalities by increasing renal hydrogen and potassium excretion in exchange for sodium and subsequent water retention.  As seen in this patient, peripheral edema may occur due to third spacing of retained fluid.

In addition to the characteristic findings associated with excessive vomiting (eg, dental caries, parotid gland enlargement), patients may also have symptoms related to volume contraction (eg, dizziness, orthostasis) and electrolyte abnormalities (eg, arrhythmias, weakness, muscle cramps, constipation).

(Choices B, C, D, and E)  Self-induced vomiting in BN can result in a hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis indicated by increased blood pH and decreased serum chloride.  Aldosterone is increased due to upregulation of the RAAS.

Educational objective:
Self-induced vomiting in bulimia nervosa results in dehydration and volume depletion, resulting in secondary hyperaldosteronism and a hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.  Symptoms may occur as result of volume contraction (eg, dizziness, orthostasis) and electrolyte abnormalities (eg, arrhythmias, weakness, muscle cramps, constipation).
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bulimia nervosa

answerChoiceList.choice: Increased Decreased Increased
Increased Increased Increased
Decreased Normal Decreased
Decreased Decreased Decreased
Normal Normal Normal

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Bulimia nervosa - medical complications.
Medical complications of anorexia nervosa and bulimia.

questionList.answerHeader: Blood pHSerum chlorideSerum aldosterone

questionList.questionText:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the office due to difficulty losing weight over the past several months.  The patient says, "I typically lose 1 or 2 pounds in the first week of dieting, but by the second week I lose control and start eating bags of cookies and potato chips."  These episodes are followed by a few days of fasting and exercising excessively.  The patient is upset about her weight and appearance but has no persistent sadness.  She enjoys her work and socializing with friends and family.  The patient has no medical conditions, but her menstrual cycle is irregular.  Weight is 67 kg (147.7 lb) and height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in).  BMI is 26.2 kg/m2.  Blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg and pulse is 86/min.  Physical examination shows dry skin but is otherwise unremarkable.  The patient has a full range of affect and no suicidal ideation.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin13 g/dL
    Hematocrit39%
    Mean corpuscular volume90 µm3 
    Platelets180,000/mm3
    Leukocytes7,500/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium136 mEq/L
    Potassium3.2 mEq/L
    Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Endocrine
    TSH2.4 µU/mL

The diagnosis is discussed, and the patient asks if any medications are available for treatment.  Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation?
questionList.explanationText:
Eating disorders

Diagnosis

Clinical features

Treatment

Anorexia nervosa

  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views of body weight & shape
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to above

Bulimia nervosa

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Binge eating & inappropriate compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain
  • Excess worrying about body shape & weight
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • SSRI (fluoxetine), often in combination with above

Binge-eating disorder

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • No inappropriate compensatory behaviors
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Behavioral weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisdexamfetamine

SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's history of recurrent binge eating, preoccupation with weight and appearance, and compensatory behaviors (ie, fasting, excessive exercise) is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.  The laboratory finding of hypokalemia is consistent with self-induced vomiting.  Other typical findings in bulimia nervosa include dry skin, hypotension, tachycardia, menstrual irregularities, erosion of dental enamel, enlarged parotid glands, and metabolic alkalosis.

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors are first-line pharmacotherapy for bulimia nervosa.  Fluoxetine has the best evidence for reducing the frequency of bingeing and purging episodes.  Although fluoxetine can be used alone, it is most effective as part of a multimodal therapy that includes nutritional rehabilitation (ie, establishing a structured and consistent meal pattern) and cognitive-behavioral therapy.

(Choice A)  The antidepressant bupropion is contraindicated in patients with active symptoms of bulimia nervosa due to an increased risk of seizures.

(Choice C)  Methylphenidate is a stimulant used primarily in the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and narcolepsy.  Decreased appetite is a common side effect.

(Choice D)  Fluoxetine is an evidence-based treatment for bulimia nervosa and should be considered in this patient.  In contrast, there is little evidence to support the use of pharmacotherapy as a first-line treatment in anorexia nervosa (which requires BMI <18.5 kg/m2 for diagnosis).

(Choice E)  The antipsychotic olanzapine typically causes weight gain.  It has been used as an adjunct treatment in anorexia nervosa but is not indicated in bulimia nervosa.

(Choice F)  Orlistat, a weight-loss drug that inhibits pancreatic lipases, is used in the treatment of obesity (eg, BMI ≥30 kg/m2).

Educational objective:
Fluoxetine is first-line pharmacotherapy for bulimia nervosa.  Best results are achieved as part of a multimodal therapy that includes cognitive-behavioral therapy and nutritional rehabilitation.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bulimia nervosa

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Bulimia nervosa
Psychopharmacological advances in eating disorders.
Psychopharmacologic treatment of eating disorders: emerging findings.

questionList.questionText:
A 19-year-old woman comes to the university health center due to "feeling cold all the time."  She wears sweaters despite the warm weather and sleeps with multiple blankets at night.  The patient also states that she has had difficulty losing weight and wonders if a thyroid problem could be causing her symptoms.  She says, "I go to the gym at least 5 times a week, but I feel like I'm stuck at the same weight.  I've even cut bread from my diet because it was making me constipated."  Menarche was at age 12, and the patient's last menstrual period was 2 months ago.  Family history is significant for Graves disease in her mother and Sjögren syndrome in her maternal grandmother.  Temperature is 36.2 C (97.2 F), blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, pulse is 38/min, and respirations are 16/min.  BMI is 15 kg/m2.  The patient is alert and cooperative but appears tired.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Serum chemistry
    Sodium136 mEq/L
    Potassium2.9 mEq/L
    Chloride96 mEq/L
    Blood urea nitrogen14 mg/dL
    Creatinine0.6 mg/dL
    Calcium8 mg/dL
    Glucose78 mg/dL
    Magnesium2.0 mg/dL
    Phosphorus2 mg/dL
 
Endocrine
    Thyroid function tests
        TSH4.5 µU/mL
        Thyroxine (T4), serum4.0 µg/dL
        Triiodothyronine (T3), serum 65 ng/dL
  
Urine hCGnegative

Oral electrolyte supplements are administered.  Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Anorexia nervosa

Clinical features

  • Underweight (BMI <18.5 kg/m2)
  • Fear of weight gain, distorted body image

Treatment

  • Psychotherapy (individual, family, group)
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if severe/refractory

Indications for hospitalization

  • Bradycardia (<40/min), dysrhythmia
  • Hypotension (<80/60 mm Hg), orthostasis
  • Hypothermia (<35 C [95 F])
  • Electrolyte disturbance, marked dehydration
  • Organ compromise (renal, hepatic, cardiac)
  • <70% expected weight (BMI <15 kg/m2)

Anorexia nervosa is an eating disorder that usually begins in adolescence.  It is characterized by distorted body image, determined dieting, and phobic avoidance of many foods, resulting in unsafe weight loss.  Risk factors include high-achieving, type-A personalities and participation in activities in which there is pressure to be slender (eg, ballet, running).  To lose weight, patients may fast and/or exercise excessively (restricting subtype) or compensate for binge eating with laxatives or vomiting (purging subtype).  Many patients also have secondary amenorrhea.

Nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy (ie, individual, group, family) are the primary interventions for medically stable patients.  Indications for hospitalization include signs of dehydration, unstable vital signs, cardiac dysrhythmias, electrolyte disturbances, organ involvement due to malnutrition, or very low weight.  This patient is medically unstable and fulfills criteria for hospitalization (pulse < 40/min, blood pressure < 80/60 mm Hg, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia).  Meals should be supervised; some patients may require nasogastric tube feeding.

(Choices A and C)  These medications are generally used as second-line adjunctive treatments.  Olanzapine may aid in weight restoration and can be considered if nutritional counseling and psychotherapy are ineffective.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors such as fluoxetine can be helpful if comorbid depression or anxiety symptoms do not resolve with refeeding.  Fluoxetine is used as primary treatment for bulimia nervosa (not anorexia nervosa).

(Choice B)  Patients with anorexia nervosa often have low T3 and/or T4 levels (also known as euthyroid-sick syndrome) due to the body's adaption to chronic nutritional depletion.  Thyroid replacement therapy is not indicated as these levels will normalize with adequate weight gain.  Replacement therapy is also potentially dangerous in these patients due to the risk for cardiac arrhythmias and osteopenia.

(Choices E and F)  Psychotherapy and nutritional rehabilitation are the mainstay of treatment for medically stable patients, but this patient requires prompt inpatient stabilization rather than outpatient referral.

Educational objective:
Indications for hospitalization in patients with anorexia nervosa include unstable vital signs, cardiac dysrhythmias, electrolyte derangements, and severely low body weight.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Anorexia nervosa

answerChoiceList.choice: Refer for cognitive-behavioral therapy, with follow-up in 2 weeks
Refer for nutritional rehabilitation, with follow-up in 2 weeks

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Medical complications of anorexia nervosa and their treatments: an update on some critical aspects.
Medical complications of anorexia nervosa and bulimia.
Initial evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after fainting at home.  The patient is an avid runner and follows a strict diet and exercise regimen.  She has been on a special juice fast and is training for a marathon with her husband.  The patient describes feeling "out of control" and has periods during which she craves sweet foods and eats "everything in sight"; afterward, she feels depressed and guilty and tries to compensate by fasting and running an additional 5 miles the next day.  She breaks down in tears and says she is afraid that her husband will leave her because of her "disgusting body."  Review of systems is unremarkable except for menstrual irregularity.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 98/62 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respirations are 14/min.  BMI is 20 kg/m2.  Physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Eating disorders

Diagnosis

Clinical features

Treatment

Anorexia nervosa

  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views of body weight & shape
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to first-line treatments

Bulimia nervosa

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Inappropriate compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain
  • Excessive worrying about body shape & weight
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • SSRI (fluoxetine), often in combination with first-line treatments

Binge eating disorder

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • No inappropriate compensatory behaviors
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Behavioral weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisdexamfetamine, topiramate

SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's preoccupation with body shape and recurrent eating binges followed by fasting and excessive exercise are suggestive of bulimia nervosa.  Loss of control during binges, followed by feelings of disgust, guilt, and depression, is common.  Although patients with bulimia nervosa often engage in self-induced vomiting, this symptom is not necessary for the diagnosis.  Other compensatory behaviors include fasting, excessive exercise (as in this patient), and misuse of laxatives, enemas, diuretics, and diet pills.  Binges and inappropriate compensatory behaviors must occur at least once a week for 3 months for the diagnosis.  In contrast to individuals with anorexia nervosa, patients with bulimia nervosa are normal weight to overweight.

Signs of bulimia nervosa may include hypotension, tachycardia, dry skin, and menstrual irregularities.  Electrolyte abnormalities (eg, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis), erosion of dental enamel, and parotid hypertrophy can be seen in patients who vomit regularly.  Treatment consists of nutritional rehabilitation, cognitive-behavioral therapy, and pharmacotherapy with fluoxetine.

(Choice A)  Anorexia nervosa may also involve binge eating and compensatory behavior (binge eating/purging subtype of anorexia).  The key distinction is body weight.  Patients with bulimia nervosa have normal to increased weight, whereas those with anorexia nervosa generally have a BMI of ≤18.5 kg/m2.  This patient's BMI (20 kg/m2) is within normal range.

(Choice B)  Avoidant/restrictive food intake disorder typically begins in infancy or early childhood and is characterized by food avoidance due to dislike of the sensory components of certain foods or the experience of eating.

(Choice C)  Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating but does not include the inappropriate compensatory behaviors seen in bulimia nervosa.

(Choice D)  Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by intense preoccupation with a perceived defect (or defects) in physical appearance.  It would not be diagnosed in an individual preoccupied with weight gain who meets the criteria for an eating disorder.

Educational objective:
Bulimia nervosa involves recurrent binge eating and compensatory behaviors.  In contrast to patients with anorexia nervosa, those with bulimia nervosa are normal weight to overweight.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bulimia nervosa

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Medical complications of anorexia nervosa and bulimia.
Bulimia nervosa-nonpurging subtype: closer to the bulimia nervosa-purging subtype or to binge eating disorder?
Epidemiology, course, and outcome of eating disorders.

questionList.questionText: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother, who became concerned after hearing her daughter vomit in the bathroom on 2 separate occasions last week.  The patient is preparing for a debate competition and says that she occasionally vomits from nervousness before an event.  She describes intense pressure to perform well in school and gain admission to a prestigious college.  Her mother adds that the patient is very self-conscious and frequently worries that her classmates dislike her and that her school uniform makes her stomach look "huge."  The patient takes no medications and has no drug allergies.  Temperature is 36.2 C (97.2 F), blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 16/min.  BMI for age is at the 4th percentile.  The patient appears slightly anxious and wears baggy clothing.  Physical examination shows dental caries, bilateral parotid gland enlargement, scars on the dorsum of the right hand, and a scaphoid abdomen with normal bowel sounds.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questionList.explanationText:
Eating disorders

Diagnosis

Clinical features

Treatment

Anorexia nervosa

  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views of body weight & shape
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to first-line treatments

Bulimia nervosa

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Inappropriate compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain
  • Excessive worrying about body shape & weight
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • SSRI (fluoxetine), often in combination with first-line treatments

Binge eating disorder

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • No inappropriate compensatory behaviors
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Behavioral weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisdexamfetamine, topiramate

SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's significantly low body weight, distorted body perception, and physical signs consistent with self-induced vomiting are suggestive of anorexia nervosa.  Patients with anorexia nervosa can have a range of abnormal eating behaviors, which are classified as the restricting subtype (ie, dieting and fasting without binge/purge behavior) and the binge/purge subtype, as seen in this patient.  Significantly low body weight (BMI generally ≤18.5 kg/m2 in adults) is a core symptom of anorexia nervosa and the key feature that distinguishes it from bulimia nervosa, in which BMI is at or above normal.  Anorexia nervosa has a typical onset in adolescence and is associated with participation in activities with pressure to be thin (eg, gymnastics, ballet).

On physical examination, the most striking finding is emaciation.  Other findings include bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, hair loss, dry skin, and lanugo (ie, fine, downy body hair).  Although common, amenorrhea is not required for diagnosis.  Findings related to self-induced vomiting in the binge/purge subtype include parotid gland hypertrophy, pharyngeal erythema, dental caries, scars or calluses on the hand from contact with the teeth (ie, Russell sign), and electrolyte abnormalities.

(Choice B)  Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent binges with no compensatory behaviors (eg, purging, fasting).

(Choice C)  Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by preoccupation with a perceived bodily defect (eg, shape of nose, body hair).  This patient's preoccupation is confined to her weight/size (ie, "huge" stomach), which when combined with her significantly low body weight and purging behaviors, is most consistent with anorexia nervosa.

(Choice D)  The key difference in differentiating anorexia nervosa from bulimia nervosa in adolescents is weight that is significantly lower than expected for age and developmental course.  In contrast, patients with bulimia nervosa typically maintain a normal weight.

(Choice E)  Generalized anxiety disorder is characterized by excessive preoccupation with multiple worries and does not explain this patient's low weight, distorted body image, or evidence of repeated purging.

Educational objective:
Signs of self-induced vomiting include parotid gland hypertrophy, pharyngeal erythema, dental caries, scars or calluses on the hand, and electrolyte abnormalities.  The binge/purge subtype of anorexia nervosa can be differentiated from bulimia nervosa by significantly low body weight.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Anorexia nervosa

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Medical complications of anorexia nervosa.
Initial evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa.

questionList.questionText:
A 20-year-old woman comes to the office due to "feeling low" for the past 2 months.  The patient says, "All I do is sleep and cry.  I lost my job last week, and now I have to move in with my parents.  I feel like a failure."  She is upset that she has gained weight and says, "My weight was the only positive thing going for me, but now I don't even have that.  My junk food cravings have gotten worse, but I've been too tired to go to the gym to make up for it."  The patient does not use alcohol or recreational drugs and takes no medications.  Medical history is insignificant.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 106/69 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min.  On physical examination, the thyroid gland is normal to palpation.  The lungs are clear to auscultation and heart sounds are normal.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin14 g/dL
Platelets200,000/mm3
Leukocytes8,000/mm3
Serum chemistry
Sodium136 mEq/L
Potassium3.2 mEq/L
Chloride93 mEq/L
Bicarbonate31 mEq/L
Creatinine0.8 mg/dL
Endocrine
TSH3.4 µU/mL

Which of the following medications would be contraindicated in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Major adverse effects of antidepressants

SSRIs & SNRIs

  • Headache, fatigue
  • Nausea, dizziness
  • Somnolence or insomnia
  • Weight gain or loss
  • Anxiety
  • Sexual dysfunction
  • Serotonin syndrome

Tricyclic antidepressants

  • Sedation, dry mouth, constipation, blurry vision
  • Weight gain, urinary retention
  • QT-interval prolongation, arrhythmias
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Sexual dysfunction

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors

  • Hypotension, dizziness
  • Weight gain
  • Involuntary muscle jerks
  • Sedation, dry mouth, constipation
  • Tyramine interaction: hypertensive crisis
  • Sexual dysfunction

Bupropion

  • Insomnia, anxiety/agitation, seizures
  • Weight loss, decreased appetite

Mirtazapine

  • Weight gain, increased appetite
  • Drowsiness
  • Hyperlipidemia

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

Although this patient's chief concern is depression, her laboratory findings of hypokalemia and hypochloremia are classic signs of self-induced vomiting, one of the most common methods of purging.  In addition, suggestive binges (worsened junk food cravings) with references to compensatory behaviors ("go to the gym to make up for it") and the undue influence of weight on self-worth ("weight was the only positive thing going for me") are concerning for an active eating disorder (eg, bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa).

Electrolyte abnormalities associated with purging behaviors increase the risk for seizures.  In patients with eating disorders who require an antidepressant, selection of the particular pharmacotherapy should consider the effects on seizure threshold.  The norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor bupropion may lower seizure threshold.  Therefore, it is contraindicated in patients with bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa, or epilepsy.  When not contraindicated, bupropion offers unique benefits as an antidepressant because it is not associated with weight gain or sexual dysfunction.

(Choices B and E)  The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) fluoxetine and the serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor venlafaxine are not contraindicated in this patient.  SSRIs are common treatment options for both depression and bulimia nervosa; fluoxetine is used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa because it can decrease binge eating and vomiting episodes.

(Choice C)  Mirtazapine is not an ideal treatment option for this patient because it stimulates appetite and causes significant drowsiness, but there is no absolute contraindication to its use.  Like bupropion, the alpha-2 adrenergic antagonist antidepressant mirtazapine does not cause sexual dysfunction.

(Choice D)  Trazodone is a mild serotonin reuptake inhibitor with antagonist activity at the 5-HT2A and 5-HT2C receptors.  It is commonly added to first-line antidepressants for the management of insomnia in depression.  Although trazodone would not be optimal due to the adverse effects of sedation and orthostatic hypotension, there are no contraindications in this patient.

Educational objective:
Bupropion is associated with an increased risk for seizures.  It is contraindicated in patients with seizure disorders, anorexia nervosa, or bulimia nervosa.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Antidepressants

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Atypical antidepressants
The safety, tolerability and risks associated with the use of newer generation antidepressant drugs: a critical review of the literature.

questionList.questionText:
An 18-year-old woman comes to the office due to hair loss.  The patient says, "I can't even brush or wash my hair because it just falls out.  I've already been so stressed since college started, and losing my hair is making everything worse."  She has felt "overwhelmed" with adjusting to college and is also working part-time at a coffee shop.  The patient says, "I've felt pretty low—my life isn't going as planned, and I don't know how to get back on track."  She says the only thing that makes her feel good is cycling, which she does for 1-2 hours every day.  The patient also adheres to a strict diet to "maintain a good body image."  She has no other medical conditions and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg, pulse is 60/min, and respirations are 14/min.  BMI is 17.5 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows generalized thinning of the hair with no scarring of the scalp.  The skin is dry with no rashes.  The remainder of the examination is unremarkable, and the patient has no suicidal ideation.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin11.4 g/dL
    Platelets260,000/mm3
    Leukocytes8,200/mm3
Serum chemistry
    Sodium140 mEq/L
    Potassium3.8 mEq/L
    Creatinine0.6 mg/dL
TSH0.6 µU/mL

Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's condition?
questionList.explanationText:
Anorexia nervosa

Clinical features

  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Fear of weight gain, distorted body image

Medical complications

  • Osteoporosis
  • Amenorrhea
  • Lanugo, hair loss, dry skin
  • Enlarged parotid glands (if binge/purge type)
  • Hypotension, hypothermia, bradycardia
  • Cardiac atrophy, arrhythmias

Treatment

  • Psychotherapy (individual, family, group)
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if severe/refractory

This patient's low body weight (BMI <18.5 kg/m2), fear of weight gain, preoccupation with body image (eg, strict dieting despite being underweight, intense exercise), hair loss, and dry skin are suggestive of anorexia nervosa (AN).  Dermatological complications of AN are common and may include dry, scaly skin; hair loss; and lanugo (fine, downy hair).  Because patients with AN frequently have limited insight or attempt to hide their disorder, clinicians must be alert for physical signs of AN in underweight patients.  Behavioral manifestations commonly associated with AN include dysphoria, anxiety, and perfectionism.

First-line treatment for AN consists of nutritional rehabilitation (eg, refeeding, establishing and reinforcing normal eating patterns) and psychotherapy.  Weight restoration through nutritional rehabilitation is a key component of treatment because it can reverse many of the medical and psychiatric complications due to malnutrition.

(Choice A)  Biofeedback (ie, using physiological monitoring as feedback) and relaxation techniques are primarily used to treat conditions involving muscle tension, anxiety, and pain.  They do not address disordered eating behavior and are not treatments for AN.

(Choices B and F)  Intradermal corticosteroid injections are indicated for alopecia areata, which causes discrete patches of hair loss rather than generalized hair thinning.  Topical minoxidil therapy has been used to treat male pattern hair loss as well as female pattern hair loss, which classically causes frontal scalp or scalp vertex hair loss.  Neither would explain this patient's low BMI and fear of weight gain.  Her hair loss should improve with AN management and weight restoration.

(Choice D)  The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor fluoxetine is a first-line treatment in bulimia nervosa (which would not be associated with a BMI <18.5 kg/m2); antidepressant medications are not effective in the treatment of AN.  Comorbid mild to moderate depression typically improves with nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy.

(Choice E)  Low-normal TSH levels are characteristic of AN and do not require treatment.  Patients with AN may have low levels of T3 and/or T4 (euthyroid sick syndrome) due to the body's adaptation to nutritional depletion.  Thyroid hormone replacement is not indicated because thyroid hormone levels will normalize with adequate weight gain.

Educational objective:
Dermatological complications of anorexia nervosa (AN) include dry, scaly skin; hair loss; and lanugo.  First-line treatment for AN consists of nutritional rehabilitation and psychotherapy.  Most medical complications of AN (eg, hair loss) improve with weight restoration.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Anorexia nervosa

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Anorexia nervosa
Nutritional rehabilitation in anorexia nervosa: review of the literature and implications for treatment.
Initial evaluation, diagnosis, and treatment of anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa.
Medical complications in anorexia and bulimia nervosa.

questionList.questionText: A 33-year-old woman comes to the office for "help losing weight."  She says, "I'm really trying, but I haven't seen any results."  The patient has tried various diets but gained 5 pounds in the past month.  She feels "defeated" and says, "I've never lasted longer than a day on a diet.  I end up feeling sorry for myself, and before I know it, I've eaten an entire cake.  Even though I feel disgusting afterward, I still do it a few times a week."  The patient has been avoiding meals with friends and family because of embarrassment about overeating.  She reports no difficulty with sleep, energy, or concentration.  Medical history is insignificant.  Mental status examination shows an overweight woman wearing loose clothing.  She is cooperative and has a reactive affect.  Treatment options are discussed, and the patient prefers to start medication.  Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Eating disorders

Diagnosis

Clinical features

Treatment

Anorexia nervosa

  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Intense fear of weight gain
  • Distorted views of body weight & shape
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • Olanzapine if no response to first-line treatments

Bulimia nervosa

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • Inappropriate compensatory behavior to prevent weight gain
  • Excessive worrying about body shape & weight
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Nutritional rehabilitation
  • SSRI (fluoxetine), often in combination with first-line treatments

Binge eating disorder

  • Recurrent episodes of binge eating
  • No inappropriate compensatory behaviors
  • Lack of control during eating
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Behavioral weight loss therapy
  • SSRI
  • Lisdexamfetamine, topiramate

SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor.

This patient's repeated episodes of eating an excessive quantity of food in a discrete period multiple times per week, associated with loss of control, disgust, and embarrassment, are consistent with binge eating disorder (BED).  The most prevalent eating disorder in the United States, BED has negative repercussions for physical health, including increased risk for obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension, as well as comorbid psychiatric disorders such as depression, anxiety, and recreational drug use.  BED can be differentiated from bulimia nervosa by the absence of inappropriate compensatory behaviors (eg, vomiting, excessive exercise, starvation).  Although patients with BED are more likely to be overweight or obese, they can also be of normal weight.

Psychotherapy (eg, cognitive-behavioral therapy, interpersonal therapy) is first-line treatment, providing demonstrated short- and long-term benefits on the reduction of binge eating episodes.  For patients preferring pharmacotherapy, antidepressants are effective in reducing binge eating episodes.  Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are commonly used due to comparative efficacy and tolerability, and sertraline is approved for use in BED.  Although patients may be concerned about the risk for weight gain with SSRIs, antidepressants typically do not cause weight change when used for BED.  Other medication options include the stimulant lisdexamfetamine and the antiepileptic agent topiramate.

(Choices A and C)  Both combination bupropion-naltrexone and orlistat are approved for the management of obesity; however, neither has demonstrated efficacy in the management of BED.  Although bupropion is specifically contraindicated in patients at risk for purging behaviors (eg, bulimia nervosa, anorexia nervosa), it should also be used with caution in patients with other eating disorders because patients may not reveal purging behaviors.  In contrast, SSRIs' safety, tolerability, and effectiveness make them preferred options in BED.

(Choice B)  Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic medication that is also used as a mood stabilizer; however, it is not effective in the management of BED.

(Choice D)  The sympathomimetic weight loss agent phentermine is not recommended for use in BED due to a lack of evidence for efficacy and the potential for adverse effects, including hypertension, tachycardia, and cardiac ischemia.

Educational objective:
Binge eating disorder is characterized by repeated episodes of excessive eating accompanied by a loss of control and subsequent distress.  The most effective treatment is psychotherapy.  Common medication options include selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (eg, sertraline), lisdexamfetamine, and topiramate.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Binge eating disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The American Psychiatric Association practice guideline for the treatment of patients with eating disorders.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old primigravid patient at 8 weeks gestation comes to the office to establish prenatal care.  She has felt intermittently nauseous for the past 2 weeks, resulting in vomiting once every morning.  Her appetite is unpredictable; at times, she does not eat breakfast or lunch and then eats more than she intended for dinner.  The patient shares that she has noticed that she already looks pregnant, and that she recently had to switch to wearing maternity clothing.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  The patient takes a prenatal vitamin every morning.  Vital signs are normal.  Weight has decreased by 2 kg (4.4 lb) compared to her prepregnancy weight; BMI is 21 kg/m2.  Physical examination shows no abnormalities.  Transvaginal ultrasound shows a single intrauterine gestation with a heart rate of 150/min.  Complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel are normal.  Urinalysis is negative for ketones.  Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient's vomiting?
questionList.explanationText:
Nausea and vomiting during pregnancy affects many women in the first trimester and is relatively mild with no associated weight loss, hypovolemia, or electrolyte abnormalities.  Most cases of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy typically resolve by the mid-second trimester; therefore, management is usually supportive with dietary modifications (eg, small, scheduled meals; taking medications with food/at night) and vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) therapy (Choices A, C, D, and E).

However, some cases of nausea and vomiting during pregnancy can mask an underlying eating disorder, as in this patient with potential concerning findings, including:

  • Weight loss with an already relatively low BMI

  • Unpredictable appetite (suggesting dysregulated eating habits) with skipping meals (suggesting possible caloric restriction) followed by episodes of overeating (suggesting possible binge eating)

  • Distorted view of body weight and shape, evidenced by the perception of "looking pregnant" despite her early gestational age (when the uterus is still below the pubic symphysis) and her switch to maternity clothing despite weight loss

Therefore, this patient requires additional evaluation for disordered eating behaviors (eg, self-induced vomiting, purging, excessive exercise).  In some women with eating disorders, pregnancy is an added stressor that increases disordered eating behaviors.  These patients are at increased risk for obstetric complications (eg, spontaneous abortion, low birth weight, microcephaly).  Therefore, patients with an eating disorder during pregnancy will benefit from nutritional counseling, setting expectations for pregnancy-related changes in body weight and size, and psychotherapy to establish or reinforce normal eating patterns.

Educational objective:
Mild nausea and vomiting during pregnancy is common in the first trimester.  However, patients with concerning findings (eg, weight loss, distorted body image, disordered eating behaviors) require evaluation for an underlying eating disorder.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bulimia nervosa

answerChoiceList.choice: Advise the patient to eat small, scheduled meals
Prescribe vitamin B<font size="2"><sub>6</sub></font> (pyridoxine) and reevaluate in 2 weeks
Provide reassurance and routine prenatal care
Recommend changing prenatal vitamin dose to the evening

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Nausea and vomiting of pregnancy.
Patterns of remission, continuation and incidence of broadly defined eating disorders during early pregnancy in the Norwegian Mother and Child Cohort Study (MoBa).

questionList.questionText:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the emergency department due to eye redness.  The patient reports sudden-onset redness of the left eye without pain, discharge, or vision abnormalities.  She also has occasional muscle cramps but reports no other symptoms.  The patient has no other medical conditions and takes no medications.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs.  Temperature is 36.5 C (97.7 F), blood pressure is 102/57 mm Hg, and pulse is 96/min.  On physical examination, the patient appears anxious about the eye redness.  Left eye examination shows a subconjunctival hemorrhage.  The right eye appears normal; bilateral visual acuity and funduscopy findings are normal.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
Hemoglobin13 g/dL
Platelets300,000/mm3
Leukocytes7,500/mm3
Serum chemistry
Sodium134 mEq/L
Potassium3.2 mEq/L
Chloride92 mEq/L
Bicarbonate30 mEq/L
Creatinine0.8 mg/dL

Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Important risk factors that increase pretest probability
for eating disorder

Epidemiologic characteristics

  • Adolescent
  • Female
  • LGBTQ+

Psychiatric disorders

  • ADHD
  • OCD
  • Anxiety disorder

Psychosocial factors

  • Childhood sexual trauma
  • Childhood appearance-related teasing
  • High-pressure career or sport

Medical signs

  • GI fluid loss (eg, hypokalemia, chloride depletion alkalosis, cramps)
  • Endocrine disruption (eg, amenorrhea, osteoporosis)
  • Vomiting (eg, dental erosions, salivary gland enlargement, subconjunctival hemorrhage)

ADHD = attention deficit hyperactivity disorder; GI = gastrointestinal; LGBTQ+ = lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer/questioning; OCD = obsessive-compulsive disorder.

This patient with a subconjunctival hemorrhage (SH) also has signs of gastrointestinal fluid loss (ie, muscle cramps possibly due to hypokalemia, alkalosis with chloride depletion), raising concern for repeated vomiting.  SHs may be a result of direct trauma (eg, eye rubbing) but may also result from rapid increases in intraabdominal pressure (eg, vomiting).  In an otherwise healthy, young patient, self-induced vomiting (ie, purging behavior) should be suspected.

Due to the significant stigma surrounding purging behavior, patients are often reluctant to self-report.  In the presence of risk factors (eg, adolescent, female) and appropriate clinical context (eg, findings that suggest purging behavior), actively screening for eating disorders is critical.  Justifiable suspicion should elicit open-ended questioning or the use of a validated screening tool such as the SCOFF questionnaire.

Affirmative responses require further clarification: the extent of disordered eating (eg, meal descriptions) and maladaptive responses (eg, serum amylase correlating frequency of vomiting) must be assessed.  Based on this additional information, treatment recommendations can be made (eg, nutritional rehabilitation, outpatient follow-up).

(Choices B and C)  SH could point to an unrecognized bleeding disorder.  However, this patient has additional red flags for self-induced vomiting, no history of bleeding disorder, and normal hemoglobin and platelet counts; so the immediate concern should be for an eating disorder.

(Choice D)  Combination topical vasoconstrictor and antihistamine therapy is sometimes used for allergic (eg, itching, crusting, bilateral symptoms) or viral (eg, watery discharge, viral prodrome) conjunctivitis.  It does not speed up resolution of SH.  In patients with SH from purging, the SH will resolve and not recur once vomiting ceases.

(Choice E)  Investigation into an underlying cause of the SH, particularly in this patient with manifestations of self-induced vomiting, is warranted before discharge is considered.  Although most patients with eating disorders are treated as outpatients, some require inpatient management (eg, BMI <15 kg/m2, acute medical comorbidities such as pancreatitis).

Educational objective:
Subconjunctival hemorrhage and signs of gastrointestinal fluid loss (eg, hypokalemia, chloride depletion alkalosis) in an otherwise healthy patient should raise concern for self-induced vomiting as part of an eating disorder.  If red flags are present, targeted questioning is recommended.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Bulimia nervosa

answerChoiceList.choice: Obtain family history of bleeding disorder

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Risk factors for eating disorders: an umbrella review of published meta-analyses.
Identification and management of eating disorders in children and adolescents.
